Kevin, this is exactly what prompted me to ask the question in the first pl=
ace.
=A0
Semantically the two formats of the query string seem to be differ=
ent to me
=A0
Format 1 : http://localhost/MyResources/1/State=A0
In this ca=
se I am using the Id to identify a single resource among a list of resource=
s encapsulated within "MyResources" and then operating on the "State" of th=
at specific resource.
=A0
Format 2: http://localhost/MyResources/State?id=
=3D1
chooses the state of "MyResources" and provides id=3D1 as input to thi=
s state.
=A0
But web frameworks that I have worked with treat both formats =
similarly and do not make any distinction. The value of Id is parsed approp=
riately in both cases, provided the path handler is specified accordingly.
=
=A0
=A0
The REST apis exposed by the service I am developing will be used b=
y different clients and they will be programming against it . All the clien=
ts will be backend services=A0(HTML Form.Post() and ajax based UI applicati=
ons are ruled out.)
=A0
So I would like to know if semantically if the quer=
y string formats make any difference to the client? ( The implementation pa=
rt on the server is easy either ways)
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0

--- On W=
ed, 7/9/08, Kevin Duffey <andjarnic@...> wrote:

From: Kevin Duffey <=
andjarnic@...>
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Query string format
To: re=
st-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, July 9, 2008, 4:32 PM








S=
o I could be wrong here, but I thought what prashanthshenoyu describes is i=
nfact standard... in that..

http://localhost/ /MyResources/{Id}/State

wou=
ld be parsed as MyResources/ 1/State would be a complete path to a specific=
 MyResources instance (1), and with that, the State resource would be used?=


At least in using the JSR-311 with Java, I would set up a path handler fo=
r /MyResources/ {id}/State and in that method handler I could get the ID an=
d from it determine the State resource to work with, return, etc.

As for t=
he other way around

http://localhost/ /MyResources/ State?Id =3D1

This wo=
uld be a completely different resource, where MyResources/ State would be c=
omparable to the above example of MyResources/ 1, but instead of a numeric =
id value, you're using State. From that, you are passing in to the State re=
source a query string of id=3D1, thus a key/value of id/1.

The first uri a=
bove seems to be a one extra resource handler. That is to say, if you had a=


GET /MyResources
GET /MyResources/ 1
GET /MyResources/ 1/State

each woul=
d return something different.

The 2nd URI is a little different.. you only=
 have 

GET /MyResources
GET /MyResources/ State

Now, I don't know if this=
 is correct, I am very new to all this too, this is just my understanding o=
f how it would work. If I am wrong, I am very interested in knowing why/how=
 so I can learn more.

Thank you.


----- Original Message ----
From: Subbu=
 Allamaraju <subbu@subbu. org>
To: prashanthshenoyu <prashanthshenoyu@ yaho=
o.com>
Cc: rest-discuss@ yahoogroups. com
Sent: Wednesday, July 9, 2008 8:0=
3:38 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Query string format

This is strictly i=
mplementation level detail. Unless you are expecting=A0 
clients to manufac=
ture URIs by using HTML forms or URI templates or=A0 
some other pre-specif=
ied form, URIs is opaque to the client. It should=A0 
not matter what form =
you choose for constructing query strings.

Subbu

On Jul 9, 2008, at 4:27 =
AM, prashanthshenoyu wrote:

> I am currently developing a RESTful Web Serv=
ice and will be using
> query strings extensively.
>
> There seems to be no=
 guide line regarding how to form the query
> strings and parse it , in a u=
niform manner.
>
> For instance some frameworks like Windows Communication =
Foundation
> treat query strings as a part of URI.
>
> For example http://l=
ocalhost/ /MyResources/{Id}/State
>
> Here Id is treated as a query string =
and the value of Id is provided
> as a part of URI
>
> Something like this =
-> http://localhost/ /MyResources/ 1/State
>
> However most frameworks trea=
t query strings as key value pairs.
> Something like http://localhost/ /MyR=
esources/ State?Id =3D1
>
> RFC 3986 says both mechanisms MAY be used.
>
> =
Is there a uniform format for specifying the query strings?
>
>
> 


------=

Content-Type: text/html; charset=us-ascii

<table cellspacing='0' cellpadding='0' border='0' ><tr><td valign='top' style='font: inherit;'><P>Kevin, this is exactly what prompted me to ask the question in the first place.</P>
<P> </P>
<P>Semantically the two formats of the query string seem to be different to me</P>
<P> </P>
<P>Format 1 : <A href="http://localhost/MyResources/1/State">http://localhost/MyResources/1/State</A> </P>
<P>In this case I am using the Id to identify a single resource among a list of resources encapsulated within "MyResources" and then operating on the "State" of that specific resource.</P>
<P> </P>
<P>Format 2: <A href="http://localhost/MyResources/State?id=1">http://localhost/MyResources/State?id=1</A></P>
<P>chooses the state of "MyResources" and provides id=1 as input to this state.</P>
<P> </P>
<P>But web frameworks that I have worked with treat both formats similarly and do not make any distinction. The value of Id is parsed appropriately in both cases, provided the path handler is specified accordingly.</P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P>The REST apis exposed by the service I am developing will be used by different clients and they will be programming against it . All the clients will be backend services (HTML Form.Post() and ajax based UI applications are ruled out.)</P>
<P> </P>
<P>So I would like to know if semantically if the query string formats make any difference to the client? ( The implementation part on the server is easy either ways)</P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P> </P>
<P><BR>--- On <B>Wed, 7/9/08, Kevin Duffey <I><andjarnic@...></I></B> wrote:<BR></P>
<BLOCKQUOTE style="PADDING-LEFT: 5px; MARGIN-LEFT: 5px; BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid">From: Kevin Duffey <andjarnic@...><BR>Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Query string format<BR>To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com<BR>Date: Wednesday, July 9, 2008, 4:32 PM<BR><BR>
<DIV id=yiv973537097>
<DIV id=ygrp-text>
<P>
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">
<DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">So I could be wrong here, but I thought what prashanthshenoyu describes is infact standard... in that..<BR><BR><A href="http://localhost//MyResources/" target=_blank rel=nofollow>http://localhost/ /MyResources/</A>{Id}/State<BR><BR>would be parsed as MyResources/ 1/State would be a complete path to a specific MyResources instance (1), and with that, the State resource would be used?<BR><BR>At least in using the JSR-311 with Java, I would set up a path handler for /MyResources/ {id}/State and in that method handler I could get the ID and from it determine the State resource to work with, return, etc.<BR><BR>As for the other way around<BR><BR><A href="http://localhost//MyResources/State?Id" target=_blank rel=nofollow>http://localhost/ /MyResources/ State?Id</A> =1<BR><BR>This would be a completely different resource, where MyResources/ State would be comparable to the above
 example of MyResources/ 1, but instead of a numeric id value, you're using State. From that, you are passing in to the State resource a query string of id=1, thus a key/value of id/1.<BR><BR>The first uri above seems to be a one extra resource handler. That is to say, if you had a<BR><BR>GET /MyResources<BR>GET /MyResources/ 1<BR>GET /MyResources/ 1/State<BR><BR>each would return something different.<BR><BR>The 2nd URI is a little different.. you only have <BR><BR>GET /MyResources<BR>GET /MyResources/ State<BR><BR>Now, I don't know if this is correct, I am very new to all this too, this is just my understanding of how it would work. If I am wrong, I am very interested in knowing why/how so I can learn more.<BR><BR>Thank you.<BR><BR>

Unless you are expecting  <BR>clients to manufacture URIs by using HTML forms or URI templates or  <BR>some other pre-specified form, URIs is opaque to the client. It should  <BR>not matter what form you choose for constructing query strings.<BR><BR>Subbu<BR><BR>On Jul 9, 2008, at 4:27 AM, prashanthshenoyu wrote:<BR><BR>> I am currently developing a RESTful Web Service and will be using<BR>> query strings extensively.<BR>><BR>> There seems to be no guide line regarding how to form the query<BR>> strings and parse it , in a uniform
